title: Valley of the Hondo, New Mexico

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of watercolor with black crayon, on moderately thick, moderately textured, ivory wove paper (all edges trimmed), in original frame.

description: Marin made his first trip to the West in early June 1929 at the suggestion of two friends, Georgia O'Keeffe and Rebecca Strand (wife of the photographer Paul Strand). O'Keeffe' s invitation came at a good moment, because Marin was feeling the need to explore new territory and escape what he called "living in herds" in Manhattan. Marin had also been tempted to visit the West by his friend the painter Marsden Hartley's vivid descriptions of the landscape. During the summers of 1929 and 1930 Marin lived and painted in New Mexico, following the lead of several of the artists who congregated around the 291 gallery in New York. Valley of the Hondo, New Mexico was one of the group of thirty watercolors that was exhibited in 1931 at Alfred Stieglitz's gallery An American Place.
medium_display: Watercolor with black crayon, on moderately thick, moderately textured, ivory wove paper (all edges trimmed), in original frame
inscriptions: Signed and dated lower right, in brown watercolor, over black crayon: ”Marin 30”
publication_history:
American Art Resource Council no. 36-X.

Sheldon Reich, John Marin, Part II: Catalogue Raisonné(Tucson, Ariz., 1970), p. 630, no. 30.68 (ill).
exhibition_history:
New York, An American Place, "John Marin," Oct. 11-Nov. 27, 1931, one of 30 New Mexico watercolors shown.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, "John Marin," 1936, cat. 129.

University Art Museum at the University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, "Marin in New Mexico," Nov. 19-Dec. 29, 1968.

Art Institute of Chicago, "Window on the West: Chicago and the Art of the New Frontier (1890–1940)," June 28-Sept. 27, 2003, cat. 60, p. 139, fig. 46.

Art Institute of Chicago, "John Marin's Watercolors: A Medium for Modernism," Jan. 19-Apr. 17, 2011, pp. 13-19, 54-55, 72-73, figs. 42 & 60a, pl. 1; traveled to the High Museum, Atlanta, June 26-Sept. 11, 2011.
provenance_text: Alfred Stieglitz (1864–1946), New York; Stieglitz Estate (Georgia O'Keeffe (1887–1986), executor); given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1949.
copyright_notice: © 2018 Estate of John Marin / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

input: Valley of the Hondo, New Mexico
